moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4: The King's Gambit. There are many ways to continue, but one enduring theme is the threat to bring a Rook to f1 to participate quickly in the attack on the Black King. Black can accept the pawn, but must defend well.
moves.4. e5 Nd5: Strangely, in this line the "Knight on the Rim" move 4. ... Nh5 is better. As played, the Knight can be harassed.
moves.5. Bc4 c6 6. O-O b5 7. Bxd5: Showing that Black's last was a waste of a move - an unaffordable luxury in the King's Gambit. Now when Black recaptures White can follow up with 8. Nc3 forking two unprotected pawns, and meanwhile is well ahead on development.
moves.8. d4: Now Black is unable both to recapture the White Bishop and save her own. She chooses to save her own, but...
moves.8... Bb6 9. Bxf7+ Kxf7 10. Bxf4: White now has the kind of attacking setup that he normally has to sacrifice a piece for in the King's Gambit. Instead he is a pawn ahead! There are many threats of discovered attacks on the f-file, the Black Knight is gone and the Bishop is stranded on the other side of the board.
moves.10... g6 11. Bg5: Since Black's last did nothing, only weakening f6, White has plenty of time for this.
moves.11... Qe8 12. Nc3 b4: This drives the Knight to a better square...
moves.14... Kf8 15. Nh4+ Bf5 16. Nhxf5: There is no hurry to take the Black Queen - Black's King is in dreadful danger.
moves.16... Kg8 17. Ne7+ Qxe7 18. Bxe7: Not only is White a whole Queen ahead, but he has three pieces already directed against the King, and the remaining White forces can join in very soon.
moves.18... h5 19. Qf3: It's taken the White Queen until move 19 to get off her throne, and she is just in time to hand out the coup de grace.
moves.19... Nd7: Black had nothing much better. Even 19. ... Bxd4  only delays the inevitable - it does nothing to let the King out of the mating net.

gameName: Not the way to defend the KGA
